config.question: On a Friday earlier this month, Zach received an A grade on a proportional reasoning quiz. Three weeks later, he took a math test that included six proportional reasoning questions, all of which he failed. How far in Zachâ€™s memory did the material get?

choices.content: It reached his working memory (sometimes called short-term memory).
It never got into his memory at all.

answer4.response: Incorrect. Obviously it has gotten into his memory because he recalled the information long enough to get an A grade on the Friday quiz.

answer1.response: Correct. Because Zach remembers the material for more than a few minutes, it must be in his long-term memory. The other components of the human memory system hold information for much shorter time periods. It seems that although the information had been in his long-term memory, he either did not learn it well and/or he was unable to retrieve it.

answer3.response: Incorrect. Since Zach remembers the material for more than a few minutes, it must be in his long-term memory. Unless it is actively rehearsed, information in working memory (sometimes called short-term memory) lasts less than a minute.

answer2.response: Incorrect. Because Zach remembers the material for more than a few minutes, it must be in his long-term memory. Information stored in the sensory register lasts for two to three seconds at most, even less for visual information.
